Study on the combustion of toluene by acid etching assisted ultrasonic supported low content Pt catalyst Wei Liu Resources Funding acquisition Conceptualization b Xueqian Wu Writing – original draft Software Data curation a Yucen Xie Software Data curation a Yufei Xie Software Data curation a Songjian Zhao Writing – review & editing Resources Methodology a ⁎ a School of Resources and Environmental Engineering, Jiangsu University of Technology, Changzhou, Jiangsu 213001, PR China School of Resources and Environmental Engineering, Jiangsu University of Technology Changzhou Jiangsu 213001 PR China School of Resources and Environmental Engineering, Jiangsu University of Technology, Changzhou, Jiangsu 213001, PR China b Jiangsu Environmental Engineering Technology Co., Ltd. Nanjing, Jiangsu 210019, PR China Jiangsu Environmental Engineering Technology Co., Ltd Nanjing Jiangsu 210019 PR China Jiangsu Environmental Engineering Technology Co., Ltd. Nanjing, Jiangsu 210019, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Catalytic combustion technology is an effective method for the treatment of volatile organic compounds (VOCs). However, the catalytic activity of loaded noble metal catalysts is limited by factors such as high noble metal dosage and poor stability. In this study, a method for the preparation of acid etching assisted ultrasonic loaded low-content Pt-cordierite catalysts was proposed. By comparing with the 0.5 % Pt/cordierite catalyst prepared without acid etching, it was found that the catalytic activity of toluene of the 0.5 % Pt/cordierite-HNO3 catalyst was significantly improved, and the T90 of toluene combustion was only 201 ℃, which indicated that the acid etching effectively promoted the interfacial bonding between the active component Pt and the carrier. Finally, it was confirmed by XPS that the active component Pt in the 0.5 % Pt/cordierite-HNO3 catalyst existed in multiple valence states, which effectively promoted the catalytic combustion of toluene. Graphical Abstract Keywords Supported catalyst Pt active component Catalytic oxidation Toluene Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) with boiling points ranging from 50°C to 260°C is emitted in large quantities mainly in the industrial production, transportation and building decoration [1,2]. In recent years, the prevalent use of organic solvents in industry has led to the emission of VOCs by as much as 42 %, which has exceeded the standard for the control of unorganized emission of VOCs set by China (GB 37822–2019). Among them, toluene is regarded as a major precursor in secondary pollution, and photochemical reactions with NOx under sunlight form ozone (O3) and fine particulate matter (PM2.5 and PM10), which in turn contribute to urban haze and photochemical smog [3,4]. In addition, as typical VOCs, toluene can cause the "triple effect" (carcinogenicity, teratogenicity, and mutagenicity) in human beings through prolonged exposure or direct inhalation of large amounts of toluene [5,6]. Therefore, the management of VOCs is essential for the protection of human health and the sustainability of ecosystems. The catalytic oxidation method is known as the most economically efficient and applicable treatment technology due to significant advantages such as high efficiency, low operating temperature, high selectivity and no secondary pollution [7–9]. The core of catalytic oxidation technology is the development of catalysts, which usually can be divided into precious metal catalysts (Au, Pt, Pd, etc. as the active component) [10,11] and non-precious metal catalysts (Mn, Cu, Co, etc. as the active component) [12,13]. Non-precious metal catalysts are limited in further application due to the high initiation temperature, the low adaptability to complex reaction environments and other factors [14]. Precious metal catalysts are commonly used for the elimination of VOCs due to low ignition temperature and excellent catalytic activity. In recent decades, precious metal catalysts have been widely used in industrial catalysis, resulting in the consumption of a large amount of precious metal resources every year. Therefore, reducing the content of precious metals in catalysts is an important way to effectively alleviate the consumption of precious metals. Currently, the application of precious metal catalysts is mainly loaded with a low content of precious metals through the selection of suitable carriers, and the interaction between the interfacial structure of the carriers and the precious metals to realize the effective loading of precious metals and excellent catalytic performance. Pt and Pd metals are usually studied as the main loaded precious metals due to high catalytic activity for VOCs at low temperatures [15]. Common carriers for loading precious metals include Al2O3, SiO2, TiO2, activated carbon and cordierite (2MgO2Al2O35SiO2) [16,17]. Among them, cordierite composite carrier of honeycomb ceramics is a precious metal catalyst carrier nowadays. It has the advantages of good mechanical strength, which can make the active component loaded more evenly on surface, and high porosity and good heat resistance, etc. Cordierite has become an excellent carrier for loading precious metals. The binding of precious metals with cordierite carriers has been studied usually with binding agent for better dispersion and binding of precious metals on the carriers. Kiran K. Sanap et al. [18] used hydrazine hydrate as a reducing agent and synthesized 0.2 %Pt-0.58 %Pd-cordierite bimetallic nanoparticles showed good H2 catalytic activity at low temperatures. The binding effect between cordierite and precious metals was effectively improved by the use of reducing agent to enhance the catalytic activity. Li et al. [19] cleverly coated cordierite with graphene, which not only enhanced the binding ability of Pd to cordierite, but also strengthened the catalytic activity and product desorption performance of Pd to toluene. In the existing studies, combining noble metals with cordierite by means of additives not only required high noble metal loading, but also caused the catalyst inactivation due to agglomeration of the noble metals bound by the additives at higher temperatures. Therefore, the preparation of low precious metal-cordierite molding catalysts by a simpler and more feasible modification method is more meaningful for practical applications. Acid etching is a common method to rebuild the surface. For example, Li et al. [20] synthesized Co3O4 with a large number of oxygen vacancies and acid site defects by acid etching. More active sites and improved redox properties showed good catalytic activity for methane combustion. Ge et al. [21] found that the crystal structure of Mn2O3 did not change significantly after acid treatment, but due to the large amount of surface Mn4+, which promoted surface oxygen migration as well as low-temperature reduction properties, the catalytic activity for toluene oxidation was improved. However, few studies have used acid etching for the study of improving the interfacial properties of cordierite carriers bound to Pt [22]. Acid etching facilitates the improvement of the surface structure of cordierite and the reorganization [23] by acid etching, generating new sites favorable for the binding of precious metals and facilitating the dispersion of precious metals. In addition, acid treatment has the advantages of being convenient and green. The acid treatment was not carried out under high temperature and high pressure, and the acid after the reaction can also be recycled and reused. The loading of Pt by acid-etched cordierite carrier-assisted ultrasonic loading technique can achieve high dispersion and stable binding of Pt on the surface of cordierite. However, there are fewer studies on the preparation of monolithic catalyst by acid-etched cordierite-assisted ultrasonic loading technique. In this study, it is proposed to use ultrasound-assisted loading of Pt onto acid-etching-based cordierite to form a noble metal catalyst with high combustion efficiency and economic benefits. The catalyst is used for the catalytic oxidation of toluene in industrial exhaust gases. Since precious metals are limited by the price in practical applications, this study considers to control the loading of Pt within 1 %, under which the development of low content and high activity Pt-based catalysts is realized. The surface morphology and physical properties of the catalysts prepared by loading the active component Pt after acid etching of the carrier were analyzed by using XRD, H2-TPR and EPR. The combustion performance of toluene was further evaluated by gas chromatography, and the effects of loading amount, acid concentration on the performance of the catalysts were discussed in depth, as well as the long-term stability and water resistance of the catalysts were considered. Finally, the elemental valence changes on the catalyst surface before and after use were investigated by XPS to hypothesize the possible mechanisms of toluene combustion. Our research provides ideas and methods for the development of molding catalysts for efficient toluene combustion. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals and materials All analytical grade chemicals and materials were purchased from commercial suppliers and used without further purification. Toluene (98 %) was purchased from McLean, HNO3 (≥90.0 %), HCl (36 %), and H2SO4 (≥95 %) were purchased from Lingfeng Chemical Reagent Co. (Shanghai, China, Inc.). Cordierite was etched using HNO3 / HCl / H2SO4. The source of Pt was chloroplatinic acid (Pt ≥ 37.5 %, Macklin Biochemicals (Shanghai, China)). 2.2 Synthesis of materials 2.2.1 Synthesis of 0.5 wt% Pt/cordierite The catalyst was prepared by ultrasonic impregnation method. At room temperature, a certain mass of honeycomb cordierite carrier was impregnated with a solution with a mass fraction of 0.5 % Pt. After ultrasonic impregnation for 0.5 h, it was removed and put into a drying oven at 100 ℃ to dry for 12 h. At the end of the process, the samples were transferred to a crucible and put into a muffle furnace to calcine at 5 ℃/min under the condition of 450 ℃ for 3 h. At last, the obtained solids were taken out to be pulverized and screened for particles of sizes between 40 and 60 mesh particles to obtain 0.5 % Pt/cordierite catalyst. 2.2.2 Synthesis of 0.5 wt% Pt/cordierite-acid The catalyst was prepared by ultrasonic impregnation method. At room temperature, cordierite was immersed in 2.5 mol/L acid solution (HNO3, HCl, H2SO4) for 1 h, and then removed and put into the drying oven at 100 ℃ to dry for 2 h. Then cordierite was put into Pt solution impregnation, and ultrasonic impregnation was carried out for 0.5 h, and then removed and put into the drying oven at 100 ℃ to dry for 12 h. After the end of the process, the samples were transferred to a crucible, and put into muffle furnace at 450 ℃ for and calcined at 5 ℃/min for 3 h. The synthesized material was pulverized and screened for particles of 40–60 mesh size to obtain 0.5 % Pt/cordierite-HNO3, 0.5 % Pt/cordierite-HCl and 0.5 % Pt/cordierite-H2SO4 catalysts. In this embodiment, the cordierite carrier obtained after acid etching and drying was calcined in a muffle furnace at 450 °C for 3 h at 5 °C/min, while other steps were kept unchanged, to obtain 0.5 % Pt/cordierite-HNO3-S, 0.5 % Pt/cordierite-HCl-S and 0.5 % Pt/cordierite-H2SO4-S Catalyst. 2.2.3 Synthesis of 0.5 wt% Pt/cordierite-xHNO3 The catalysts were prepared by ultrasonic impregnation method. At room temperature, cordierite was immersed in different concentrations of HNO3 solution (0.5 mol/L, 1.5 mol/L, 2.5 mol/L, 3.5 mol/L) for 1 h, and then removed and put into a drying oven at 100 ℃ to dry for 2 h, and then cordierite was impregnated into 0.5 % Pt solution, ultrasonically loaded for 0.5 h and then removed and put into a drying oven at 100 ℃ to dry for 12 h, at the end of which the sample was transferred to a crucible and put into a muffle furnace at 450 °C for calcination at 5 °C/min for 3 h. The synthesized material was pulverized and screened for particles of 40–60 mesh size to obtain 0.5 % Pt/cordierite-0.5HNO3, 0.5 % Pt/cordierite-1.5HNO3, 0.5 % Pt/cordierite-HNO3 and 0.5 % Pt/cordierite-3.5HNO3 catalysts. Only the loading method was changed to agitation impregnation, and other steps remained unchanged to obtain 0.5 % Pt/cordierite-CTS-HNO3 catalysts. The Pt content (wt%) in the prepared catalyst was measured experimentally and listed in Table 1. 2.3 Evaluation of toluene combustion performance The toluene combustion performance of the catalyst was evaluated in a fixed-bed quartz reactor system with a quartz tube of 7 mm I.D. Toluene was brought into the gas path by air bubbling, and the concentration of toluene was controlled at 1000 ± 50 ppm by using air as a balance gas. The toluene concentration and CO2 concentration were detected using FID detector and TCD detector in a gas chromatograph, respectively. The total gas flow rate in the experiment was 100 mL/min and the catalyst dosage was 100 mg. 2.4 Characterization of materials The microstructure of the materials was analyzed using a JEM-2010HT analytical scanning electron microscope. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained by an X-ray diffractometer (Bruker D8 Advance ECO, Germany) using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). Specific surface area and pore size of the samples were done using the Brunauer-emmett-teleler (BET) method in an ASAP 2020 specific surface area and pore size analyzer. An inductively coupled plasma emission spectrometer (ICP-OES, Optima 5300DV, Perkins Elmer) was used to analyze the Pt content of the catalysts. X-ray photoelectron spectrometry (XPS) mapping was performed using a Thermoscience KAlpha+ spectrometer with Aluminum Kα radiation. The binding energy values were adjusted to the energy of the standard C 1 s peak (284.8 eV). H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was conducted on a Micromeritics Chemisorb 2920 instrument with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a mass spectrometer (HIDEN, HPR-20 R&D). Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) examination was performed on an electron paramagnetic resonance spectrometer (Bruker, E500) at room temperature. 2.5 Kinetic measurements The details are presented in the support information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Morphological analysis of catalysts The micro-morphology of cordierite and 0.5 % Pt/cordierite and 0.5 % Pt/cordierite-HNO3 was analyzed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM). As shown in Fig. 1, the typical surface morphology of cordierite carriers can be obtained (Fig. 1a-c), where the surface is relatively rough with more small pores, which increases the contact area and provides potential for the loading of the active components. Comparing with the cordierite ultrasonically loaded catalysts with low Pt content (Fig. 1d-f), it can be observed that the acid-treated catalysts loaded with low Pt content (Fig. 1g-i) not only have a significant increase in the surface porosity and many fine particles appeared on the surface. It is shown that the active components are deeply bound and highly dispersed with the acid-etched cordierite carriers. This property provides more active sites for the catalytic oxidation as well as theoretical possibilities for the efficient combustion of toluene. Fig. 3j-l shows the EDS spectra of the 0.5 % Pt/cordierite-HNO3 catalysts, from which it can be clearly observed that Pt and O are more uniformly deposited on the surface of cordierite, with loose arrangement between particles. This further indicates the dispersion of Pt on the cordierite surface. The XRD spectra of as-synthesized catalysts was shown in Fig. 2. By analyzing the crystal structures, it can be found that the catalysts mainly exposed the rhombohedral phase characteristic peaks of cordierite (JCPDS 13–0294). When loaded with Pt, the XRD spectra of the 0.5 % Pt/cordierite and 0.5 % Pt/cordierite-HNO3 catalysts only showed at 39.76° the a weak characteristic peak of Pt species (JCPDS 04–0802) [18]. This may be due to the low Pt content lead to high dispersion in cordierite. The fact that the Pt particles were not able to form larger crystals, and thus no obvious Pt species characteristic peaks were detected. This also indicates that the loaded noble metal catalysts prepared in this study retained the crystal structure of cordierite. The weak characteristic peaks of Pt species also indicate the successful loading of Pt, which is consistent with the results obtained from the SEM analysis mentioned above. The reducibility of 0.5 % Pt/cordierite and 0.5 % Pt/Cordierite-HNO3 catalysts was studied by H2-TPR ( Fig. 3a). It was found that H2 consumption of 0.5 % Pt/Cordierite-HNO3 catalyst was nearly twice that of Pt/cordierite catalyst (Fig. 3b), indicating that there were more reducing species and active sites in 0.5 % Pt/Cordierite-HNO3 catalyst. This may be attributed to the concave and convex structure formed on the surface of cordierite after acid etching and the roughness of the surface are conducive to enhancing the contact between the carrier and the active component Pt, thus improving the load and distribution uniformity of the active component on the carrier, and effectively promote the interface bonding between the active component Pt and the carrier. As an important active site in the catalyst, oxygen vacancy plays an important role in the adsorption and activation of toluene and molecular oxygen, which can significantly improve the activity and selectivity of the catalyst. Therefore, the unpaired electrons and defects are quantified by means of electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR). Among them, 0.5 % Pt/Cordierite-HNO3 catalyst has a high oxygen vacancy signal (Fig. 3c), which indicates that the important active site of oxygen vacancy can participate in the adsorption and oxidation process of toluene. 3.2 Evaluation of toluene removal performance In Fig. 4a, it can be observed that the activity of unloaded Pt cordierite catalysts was extremely low, and the toluene combustion T90 (WHSV: 60,000 mL/(g∙h), GHSV: 26,000 h−1) of 0.5 Pt/cordierite-HCl and 0.5 %Pt/cordierite-H2SO4 catalysts prepared by HCl and H2SO4 etching of cordierite was close to 232°C. But the 0.5 % Pt/cordierite-H2SO4 catalyst exhibited higher CO2 selectivity, which may be attributed to the presence of some intermediates that inhibited the activity of the active component Pt, which in turn affected the deep oxidation process of toluene. The toluene combustion performance and CO2 selectivity of the 0.5 % Pt/cordierite catalysts without acid etching were higher than those of the two catalysts obtained by hydrochloric acid and sulfuric acid etching of cordierite. Indicating that acid etching not only affects the surface structure of cordierite through H+, but also the difference in anionic species has a certain effect on the active component Pt. The catalysts prepared by HNO3 etching cordierite had higher toluene combustion performance than the catalysts without acid treatment and were able to maintain higher toluene catalytic oxidative combustion activity. Indicating that HNO3 etching was able to deeply disrupt the surface structure of cordierite, thus generating more structures conducive to the loading of Pt and stable binding. Through the kinetic analysis of the catalysts obtained from different acid etched carriers, it was found that the apparent activation energy (Ea) of the four catalysts was ranked as follows: 41.64 KJ/mol (0.5 % Pt/cordierite-HNO3) < 45.60 KJ/mol (0.5 % Pt/cordierite) < 48.43 KJ/mol (0.5 % Pt/cordierite-HCl) < 53.06 KJ/mol (0.5 % Pt/cordierite-H2SO4). A lower Ea is favorable for breaking through the energy barrier, which indicates that the 0.5 % Pt/cordierite-HNO3 catalyst has a higher potential ability to oxidize toluene. In addition, calculation of TOF values of the four catalysts also showed that 0.5 % Pt/cordierite-HNO3 catalyst had more surface potential active sites, which was conducive to the adsorption and oxidation process of toluene.Thus, The 0.5 % Pt/cordierite-HNO3 catalyst showed more excellent catalytic oxidizing ability in the toluene combustion process. For the catalyst prepared in the study, an inductively coupled plasma emission spectrometer (ICP-OES, Optima 5300DV, Perkins Elmer) was used to analyze the Pt content of the catalysts (Table 1). Through the analysis of the actual load of Pt in the catalyst, it is found that the actual load of Pt in the prepared catalyst is lower than the theoretical load, which may be attributed to the uneven dispersion of some Pt on the surface of the catalyst. In addition, the transfer of Pt components on the catalyst surface may also lead to uneven local dispersion, and the actual load of Pt in the catalyst is slightly lower than the theoretical load measured by ICP. In Fig. 5a, the toluene combustion performance of the catalysts prepared with 0.5 % Pt loading and different acid etching, and Fig. 5b shows the CO2 selectivity curve under the same conditions. By acid etching cordierite and calcination will occur slight structural damage, the surface produces small cracks. The change of the surface structure for the formation of new structures and Pt loading provides a new environment, which is conducive to improve the full contact between toluene and the active components, and at the same time, expose more Pt active sites. As can be observed from Fig. 5a, the toluene oxidation activity of the catalysts prepared by HNO3-treated and calcined cordierite-loaded Pt was significantly higher than that of the catalysts prepared by calcined cordierite-loaded Pt after sulfuric and HCl treatments, and the CO2 yields were generally in line with the toluene combustion trend. By exploring the type of acid used for etching cordierite, it was found that the catalysts prepared by HNO3 etching of cordierite loaded with Pt had higher toluene oxidation capacity. Acid etching can increase the porosity of cordierite surface, and with the slow increase of HNO3 concentration, the porosity of cordierite increases. But with the increase of HNO3 concentration used in acid etching will lead to the decrease of the porosity of the catalyst, the pore size becomes larger, which will lead to the resulting catalyst toluene combustion ability becomes weaker. Therefore, the use of a certain concentration of HNO3 etching cordierite and then loaded with Pt can effectively improve the dispersibility and catalytic activity of Pt. Through the study of the toluene combustion performance of the catalysts obtained by etching cordierite loaded with Pt at different concentrations of HNO3 ( Fig. 6), it was found that the 0.5 % Pt/cordierite-HNO3 catalyst had higher catalytic activity. Therefore, the present study chose to etch cordierite with 2.5 mol/L HNO3 for the subsequent study of the combustion of toluene by loaded Pt. Fig. 7a shows the toluene combustion performance curves and CO2 yield curves of the catalysts prepared using both stirring and ultrasonic loading of Pt. It can be clearly observed that the toluene combustion activity of the catalysts prepared by stirring loaded Pt is poor, which may be attributed to the fact that cordierite is a honeycomb ceramic solid, and the shorter stirring time lend to make the Pt loaded incompletely and uniformly on the carrier, the stability of the active components combined by stirring loading is poor, and the agglomeration of the active components of the Pt directly leads to the reduction of the activity of the catalysts. After acid treatment, the void ratio of cordierite surface increased, and ultrasonication made it easier for Pt to enter into the voids of the carrier, and more fully loaded Pt on the carrier. In Fig. 8a, the toluene combustion curves of catalysts with different Pt loadings and the CO2 yield curves under the same conditions are shown. It can be found that the level of Pt loading in the catalyst has a direct effect on the toluene combustion performance. The T90 of toluene combustion of the catalyst prepared with 0.05 % Pt loading was greater than 280 °C, while the T90 of toluene combustion of the catalyst prepared with 0.5 % Pt loading was lower than 220 °C. The toluene combustion activity of the catalysts can be effectively improved with the increase of Pt loading. However, considering the influence of factors such as the amount of precious metal and the intermediate products of toluene combustion, a Pt loading of 0.5 % was chosen for the present study to ensure the adequate dispersion of the active components on cordierite and the high activity. Since the composition in the actual VOCs gas treatment is often complex, in which water vapor is the component that has a large impact on the catalyst activity. Thus, the study of the water resistance of the catalyst is extremely important for the catalyst to be able to achieve practical applications [24,25]. In Fig. 9, the long-term stability of toluene combustion of the catalysts at 219 °C and the test of water resistance are shown. When no water vapor is introduced, the oxidation performance of toluene is stable at about 88 %, which indicates that the active site on the surface of the catalyst can continue the adsorption oxidation of toluene and the desorption process of the product, ensuring the continuous action of the active site. When 5 % water vapor is introduced, it can be found that the oxidation performance of toluene decreases slightly and then stabilizes at about 75 %, which is attributed to the competitive adsorption of some water molecules and toluene on the catalyst surface. When the water vapor was removed, the oxidation property of toluene increased to about 80 %, indicating that the presence of water molecules occupied some of the active sites, and the reduced active sites eventually led to the oxidation property of toluene decreased by about 8 %. The high stability and water resistance showed that the desorption of toluene oxidation products and the weak adsorption of water molecules at the active site on the surface of 0.5 % Pt/cordierite-HNO3 catalyst were favorable for the continuous oxidation of toluene. The X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 10. The fine spectrum of XPS for O 1 s forms two characteristic peaks at around 529.3 eV and 531.3 eV, which belong to lattice oxygen and surface adsorbed oxygen respectively [26], and there is basically no significant change before and after the reaction (Fig. 10b). For the 0.5 % Pt/cordierite-HNO3 catalyst after use (Fig. 10c, f), three characteristic peaks of Pt species existed with values of binding energies of about 71.2 eV, 74.5 eV, and 78.3 eV, which corresponded to Pt0 in the Pt metal state and Pt2+ and Pt4+ in the ionic state, respectively [27]. It can be obtained that the XPS spectra confirmed that Pt was present in the catalyst in a mixed valence state [28,29]. By comparing the catalysts before and after use, it can be found that the content of Pt0 and Pt2+ in the catalysts after use increases, which may be because the strong oxidation of Pt4+ promotes the catalytic combustion of toluene, and the valence state of Pt after reduction becomes low. The addition of surface reactive oxygen species by adsorption of molecular oxygen can catalyze the oxidation of toluene continuously and achieve long-term stable combustion of toluene by the catalyst. Fig. 11 During the oxidation of toluene, the oxygen vacancy in the catalyst, as the active site, plays a major role in the adsorption of toluene and free oxygen. The mixed valence active Pt species played a key role in the open epoxidation of toluene as the main active site, and the active oxygen species also participated in the deep oxidation of toluene as the active site. The reactive oxygen species consumed are supplemented by molecular oxygen. In addition, the active component Pt oxidized toluene continuously through the valence cycle, some Pt was reduced to exist in the form of Pt0, and the final products of toluene combustion were mainly CO2 and H2O. 4 Conclusion In this study, 0.5 % Pt/cordierite-HNO3 catalysts were prepared by acid-etched cordierite-assisted ultrasonic loading Pt technique and used for toluene combustion studies. The Pt content of 0.5 % Pt/cordierite-HNO3 catalyst was 0.483 %. H2-TPR indicated that there are more potential active sites on the catalyst surface after acid etching, and EPR also confirmed that acid etching contributes to the formation of oxygen vacancy. In addition, the long-term stability and water resistance tests of the 0.5 % Pt/cordierite-HNO3 catalyst showed that the Pt active component had a stronger affinity for toluene, and the occupation of the active sites by water molecules was weaker, confirming the preferential adsorption of toluene on the surface of the catalyst and catalytic combustion. The 0.5 % Pt/cordierite-HNO3 catalyst prepared by the acid-etched cordierite-assisted ultrasonic loading Pt technology developed in this study not only effectively reduces the amount of precious metals used, but also improves the binding ability and dispersibility of cordierite carriers and Pt. Long-term stability and water resistance also indicate that the 0.5 % Pt/cordierite-HNO3 catalyst has excellent toluene combustion performance and good adaptability to water vapor environment. This study provides an idea for the removal of toluene from industrial waste gas. CRediT authorship contribution statement Wei Liu: Resources, Funding acquisition, Conceptualization. coredata.dc:description: Catalytic combustion technology is an effective method for the treatment of volatile organic compounds (VOCs). However, the catalytic activity of loaded noble metal catalysts is limited by factors such as high noble metal dosage and poor stability. In this study, a method for the preparation of acid etching assisted ultrasonic loaded low-content Pt-cordierite catalysts was proposed. By comparing with the 0.5 % Pt/cordierite catalyst prepared without acid etching, it was found that the catalytic activity of toluene of the 0.5 % Pt/cordierite-HNO3 catalyst was significantly improved, and the T90 of toluene combustion was only 201 ℃, which indicated that the acid etching effectively promoted the interfacial bonding between the active component Pt and the carrier. Finally, it was confirmed by XPS that the active component Pt in the 0.5 % Pt/cordierite-HNO3 catalyst existed in multiple valence states, which effectively promoted the catalytic combustion of toluene.
